Award.AwardTitle: Inverse problems for poroelastic composites with applications in bone health monitoring
Award.AbstractNarration:
This research project is directed towards developing mathematical and computational methods arising from quantitative ultrasound techniques (QUT) for detecting osteoporosis, a major public health threat affecting more than 44 million Americans. Understanding the bio-mechanical advance of the disease and developing quantitative mathematical techniques for its monitoring is the first step towards efficient treatment and prevention. Diagnostics based on QUT is relatively inexpensive and, unlike X-ray densitometry, it does not ionize the tissue. The strength of cancellous bone plays an essential role in the diagnosis of osteoporosis. The proposed work aims at developing mathematical tools for determining various parameters that describe the strength of porous-elastic materials, by probing the materials with mechanical waves such as ultrasound. The educational component emphasizes the interdisciplinary nature of the proposed research in several STEM fields. Through joint work with the PI's collaborators in mechanical and biomedical engineering, facilitated by the Center for Biomedical Engineering Research at the University of Delaware, a new interdisciplinary educational initiative linking biomedical engineering and mathematics for undergraduate and graduate student training is planned. The results from this project will be of interest to researchers who conduct laboratory experiments to study the relation between bone strength and bone micro-architecture and will open an avenue for a more accurate and reliable ultrasound devices for measuring properties of porous-elastic materials.

The goal of the research is to utilize the dehomogenization techniques to study the mathematical characterization of effective parameters relevant to mechanical properties of poroelastic materials and the governing equations of wave propagation in these materials. Poroelastic composites are two-phase composite materials consisting of elastic solid frames with fluid-saturated pore space, e.g. fluid saturated rocks, sea ice, and cancellous bone. The study of poroelasticity plays an important role in biomechanics, seismology, and geophysics. The physical properties of these composites depend not only on the constituent materials but also on the microstructure of pore space and how the viscous pore fluid interacts with the solid frame. The bulk properties are described by various 'effective parameters' that appear as coefficients of the integro-differential equations governing wave propagation through poroelastic materials when the wavelength is much larger than the scale of the microstructure. Retrieval of effective parameters through a non-destructive test using waves is essential in monitoring the health of these composites. In the course of this project, a numerical paradigm for simulating wave propagation in poroelastic composites and the inverse problem of the parameter retrieval will be developed, analyzed, and implemented. By utilizing the fact that all the effective properties in the poroelastic wave equations for a given bone sample are underpinned by the same microstructure, the computational model will be constructed from micro-CT scans in a mathematically consistent way.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project aims to study the influence of microstructure on the bulk properties of two-phase compoiste materials such as cancellous bone, which is made of elastic bone matrix and slightly viscous pore fluid. The PI and her students have spent this award period working closely with the leading researchers in biomedical engineering in order to understand what bulk properties are crucial iin describing bone health and to make a positive impact in the cancellous bone research. Along this line of interdisciplinary research, we have a paper entitled 'Mathematical quantification of the impact of microstructure on the various effective properties of bones' to appear in  Encyclopedia of Biomedical Engineering published by Elsevier.

Due to their importance in describing the transport property of bone and its relation to the pore fluid drag force, which provides a signaling mechanism for bone cells, we have focused on the dynamic permeability tensor and tortuosity tensor. Roughly speaking, the permeability quantifies how a unit of the pressure difference on opposite sides of a cancellous bone results in motion of pore fluid in the bone. The word 'dynamic' refers to the fact that when the applied pressure gradient is periodic in time with frequency f, the viscous pore fluid will respond differently with different frequencies, i.e. the permeability is a function of f. The tortuosity is inversely proportional to the permeability and it fully describes the effective drag force and energy dissipation resulting from the interaction between the viscous fluid and the solid matrix at the microscopic scale.

Despite the complex microstructure of cancellous bone and its variations between different people, we discovered that  there is a universal mathematical structure as a result of causality. WIth the help from complex analysis, we were able to quantify the influece of the microstructure on the dynamic tortuosity via an integral representation, where all the microstructual information is encoded in the positive measure supported on the real axis on the complex plane. Utilizing this mathematical structure, we also developed an efficient numerical scheme for solving the Biot-JKD equations, which are the govering equations for wave propagation in poroelastic materials. The main difficulty is the fact that this set of equations has a time-integral term (i.e. the memory term) that involves the unknowns and this make the time discretization difficult. In the literature, the way to deal with this memory term numerically has been the fractional derivative technique, which required a complicated way for creating good quadratures. The algorithm we developed provides an alternative method that is not only easier to implement but also requires less computational time. The key ingredient is the pole-residue approximation of the dynamic tortuosity function. It is guaranteed by the mathematical structure that the dynamic tortuosity can be very well approximated by a pole-residue approximant. We have developed two robust  numerical methods for computing these pole and residues from values of tortuosity at distinct frequencies. A time-domain Discontinuous-Galerkin solver for the Biot-JKD equations with memory terms has been developed and implemented, where we applied the pole-residue approximation strategy for treating the memory terms. The results will be reported in two manuscripts in preparation with titles 'On the augmented Biot-JKD equations with Pole-Residue representation of the dynamic tortuosity' and 'A Discontinuous Galerkin method for wave propagation in orthotropic poroelastic media'.

Another line of research during this award period has been the invesre problems for recovering permeability distribution from measurement on the boundary. This is a collaboration with researchers at the Center of Composite Materials (CCM) at UD and our data came from real lab measurements conducted on 2D fabric and 2D circuit senser boards. The PI and her graduate students have developed a solver for 2D problem, which is based on a Bayesian inversion scheme for the Electric Impedance Tomography (EIT) technology. We have obtained good results on locating cracks in 2D circuit senser boards. 

Four graduate students (two females and two males) and two undergraduate students have participated in the research as part of their theses work and REU projects. The results of the research have been disseminated to the biomedical engineering community through publications and international conferences.


Last Modified: 11/21/2017
Modified by: Miao-Jung Y Ou
